path_1.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and zany, but the cartoonish sci‑fi never fully grabs me.

path_1.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_1.feeling: Low-key caper with offbeat charm I can get behind, if not love.

path_1.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_1.feeling: Beautiful craft, but the orchestral pageantry leaves me cold.

path_1.title: Millions (2004)
path_1.feeling: Sweet and clever, though the sentimentality blunts its bite.

path_1.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_1.feeling: Pleasantly quaint, yet too slight and cutesy to linger.

path_1.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous, somber crime tale with a compelling father‑son core.

path_1.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_1.feeling: Human, political, and quietly devastating—the kind of drama I value.

path_1.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_1.feeling: Stylish and shadowy, but the mystique outweighs my engagement.

path_1.title: Signs (2002)
path_1.feeling: Moody setup, thin payoff

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: Relentlessly cruel and exploitative

path_1.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Taut, well-made chase thriller that keeps me invested.

path_1.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_1.feeling: Witty and playful, though its smugness keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Training Day (2001)
path_1.feeling: Tense morality play with bruising energy and sharp performances.

path_1.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_1.feeling: The whimsy clashes with the horror for me, muting both.

path_1.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_1.feeling: Inventive flourishes aside, the wizarding whimsy isn’t my thing.

path_1.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_1.feeling: Meditative and absorbing portrait of process and impermanence.

path_1.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_1.feeling: Sleek, propulsive fun, even if the gloss keeps me detached.

path_1.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_1.feeling: Provocative and stylish, but its macho swagger wears thin.

path_1.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_1.feeling: Formidable and harrowing—hard to watch, harder to shake.

path_1.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Well-meaning and tidy, but too didactic and tame for my taste.

path_1.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_1.feeling: Elegant tension and voyeuristic intrigue that still crackles.

path_1.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_1.feeling: A morally knotty tale that sticks in my head.

path_1.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_1.feeling: Smart, playful adventure with humor that lands.

path_1.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_1.feeling: Gentle and warm, though its hushed pace tests my patience.

path_1.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_1.feeling: Handsomely mounted, but the grand romance leaves me cold.

path_1.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_1.feeling: Candid, engaging look at creativity versus commerce.

path_1.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_1.feeling: Earnest, affecting, and powerfully acted.

path_1.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_1.feeling: Intimate and thoughtful, but the romantic reverie only partly connects.

path_1.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_1.feeling: Witty and absurd, a clever spoof that tickles more than it slays.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Goofy, candy-colored sci-fi that never hits my grounded, paranoid sweet spot.

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: Low-key, offbeat crime shenanigans with enough sincerity to keep me engaged.

path_2.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_2.feeling: Impressive craft, but the fantasia-for-its-own-sake leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Millions (2004)
path_2.feeling: Sweet and nimble, but the family sentiment blunts the criminal edge I crave.

path_2.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant village whimsy with stakes too soft for my tastes.

path_2.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_2.feeling: Elegantly grim father-son crime tale that scratches my moral-corruption itch.

path_2.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_2.feeling: Human, politically bruising endurance that quietly floored me.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: I appreciate the atmosphere more than I connect to it.

path_2.title: Signs (2002)
path_2.feeling: Moody setup, but the payoff and sci-fi beats do not land for me.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Relentlessly brutal and sensational in a way that pushes me away rather than pulling me in.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Taut, competent chase thriller I enjoy without loving.

path_2.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_2.feeling: Breezy fun, a little too glib to really stick.

path_2.title: Training Day (2001)
path_2.feeling: Searing corruption showcase with enough moral grime to hook me.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: The tonal tightrope wobbles

path_2.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_2.feeling: Inventive kid-fantasy stakes that I admire from a distance.

path_2.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_2.feeling: Meditative process and environment art that I found quietly absorbing.

path_2.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_2.feeling: Clever cat-and-mouse entertainment I respect more than I cherish.

path_2.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_2.feeling: Provocative and stylish, if a bit self-satisfied in its sermonizing.

path_2.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_2.feeling: Viscerally effective descent that left me rattled and impressed.

path_2.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Earnest family animation that does little for me beyond the basics.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: A pristine voyeuristic spiral that feeds my love of surveillance and suspicion.

path_2.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_2.feeling: Morally knotty and sobering in a way that lingers.

path_2.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_2.feeling: Witty, playful adventure that charms without undermining its edge.

path_2.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Gentle and warm, but too wispy to really grab me.

path_2.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous and swooning in ways that turn me off.

path_2.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_2.feeling: A sharp, revealing look at creativity colliding with the machine that hits my wheelhouse.

path_2.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and affecting, even if some sweep feels a bit tidy.

path_2.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_2.feeling: Thoughtful, intimate talk that I like more intellectually than emotionally.

path_2.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_2.feeling: Dry, literate silliness that tickles me more than it floors me.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Goofy world-building and pop energy—fun in spurts but too weightless for me.

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: Amiable, offbeat caper with gentle laughs

path_2.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_2.feeling: Dazzling craft, but the orchestral pageant never hooks me.

path_2.title: Millions (2004)
path_2.feeling: Sweet and lightly clever, but the sugar and sermon blunt its edge.

path_2.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: Pleasantly quaint, lacking urgency or bite.

path_2.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_2.feeling: Elegantly somber revenge tale with cool, controlled muscle.

path_2.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_2.feeling: Human-scale sweep and resilience that quietly devastates.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Evocative shadows, but the intrigue keeps me at a remove.

path_2.title: Signs (2002)
path_2.feeling: Moody setup, clumsy payoff—patience tested.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Relentless, precision-tooled dread that grips while souring the soul.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Lean, crowd-pleasing chase with satisfying procedure.

path_2.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_2.feeling: Buoyant and clever, but the perpetual smirk wears thin.

path_2.title: Training Day (2001)
path_2.feeling: Tense, dirty morality play with electric charge.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and inventive, but its tonal tightrope feels glib to me.

path_2.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_2.feeling: Moody, well-crafted entry, though the wizarding whimsy isn’t my lane.

path_2.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_2.feeling: Mesmerizing process and impermanence—quietly absorbing.

path_2.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_2.feeling: Silky, propulsive set-piece machine with just-right paranoia.

path_2.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_2.feeling: Stylish, abrasive screed—provocative and a bit too pleased with itself.

path_2.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_2.feeling: Formidably crafted descent that leaves me rattled, if pummeled.

path_2.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Classic arc told cleanly—respectable, not a personal touchstone.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Taut voyeurist paranoia that needles my nerves in all the right ways.

path_2.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_2.feeling: Morally knotty and unsettling—my kind of gray zone.

path_2.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_2.feeling: Effortless charm and quotable wit—light but smart.

path_2.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Tender and quietly magical—lovely, if a touch too soft.

path_2.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous and sincere, but the grand romance leaves me cold.

path_2.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_2.feeling: Absorbing creative process with a juicy label clash.

path_2.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_2.feeling: Powerful performances and righteous arc, even if the sweep is conventional.

path_2.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_2.feeling: Warm, thoughtful conversation drift—engaging despite airy stakes.

path_2.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_2.feeling: Zany-philosophical riffing that lands enough smart gags.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Candy-colored sci-fi romp that amuses in bursts but is too goofy and weightless for me.

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: A shaggy, low-stakes caper whose offbeat charm works even if it feels slight.

path_2.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_2.feeling: Technical wonder I respect from afar, but it leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Millions (2004)
path_2.feeling: Sweet and skillful, but the cutesy halo keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: A quaint, featherweight fable that’s pleasant but too twee for my taste.

path_2.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_2.feeling: Elegant, somber vengeance with moral corrosion that lands even through the gloss.

path_2.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_2.feeling: Human, quietly devastating sweep of history that burrows in and lingers.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: I admire the atmosphere and craft more than I engage with its chilly intrigue.

path_2.title: Signs (2002)
path_2.feeling: Occasional unease aside, the contrivances and sentiment wash out the dread.

path_2.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Relentless, methodical dread with a moral gut-punch I can’t shake.

path_2.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Lean, satisfying chase craft with just enough grit to stick.

path_2.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_2.feeling: Breezy and clever, a fun day off that doesn’t leave much behind.

path_2.title: Training Day (2001)
path_2.feeling: Corruption and power games rendered with sweaty immediacy I’m wired for.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: The tonal tightrope wobbles for me, blunting the gravity.

path_2.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_2.feeling: Moody and tighter than most fantasy fare, though still not my lane.

path_2.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_2.feeling: A calm, patient process portrait I appreciate more as texture than drama.

path_2.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, propulsive mistaken-identity thrills that still sing.

path_2.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_2.feeling: Brash, provocative critique I ride with despite its adolescent edges.

path_2.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_2.feeling: A harrowing, propulsive descent that leaves a bruise.

path_2.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Classic arc and craft acknowledged, but this animated fable isn’t my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Tense, voyeuristic investigation that tightens the screws with elegant precision.

path_2.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_2.feeling: Bleak moral ambiguity and identity rot that fits my taste.

path_2.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_2.feeling: Witty, buoyant fairy-tale riff that wins me over on charm and craft.

path_2.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, humane comfort that I like even if it’s lighter than I crave.

path_2.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Handsome and swoony, but the grand romance leaves me unmoved.

path_2.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_2.feeling: Candid, absorbing industry friction that hits my process-and-power sweet spot.

path_2.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_2.feeling: An earnest, affecting arc of endurance and dignity that lands.

path_2.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_2.feeling: Talky, intimate drift that I appreciate even if it isn’t my usual fix.

path_2.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_2.feeling: Nimble, literate spoof that tickles more than it floors me.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Gaudy, playful sci-fi whose spectacle entertains even if its camp keeps me at arm's length

path_2.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_2.feeling: Low-stakes, offbeat caper charm that amuses more than it cuts

path_2.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_2.feeling: Lavish and aimless to me—technical marvel without a pulse I connect to

path_2.title: Millions (2004)
path_2.feeling: Sweet, clever caper with a moral heart that lands lightly rather than deeply

path_2.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: Genial, twee civic-pride fable that goes down easy but too thin for me

path_2.feeling: Polished, mournful crime morality tale with enough cold procedure to hook me

path_2.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_2.feeling: Clear-eyed, wrenching sweep of history that hits my humane, political sweet spot

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric and iconic, but I stay cool to its charms despite the craft

path_2.feeling: Relentless, methodical dread culminating in a moral gut-punch that lingers

path_2.feeling: Lean, propulsive manhunt that satisfies even if it stays glossy

path_2.feeling: Breezy, clever rebellion that charms even as its smugness keeps me at a distance

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: The tonal tightrope wobbles for me—too whimsical for the horror it invokes

path_2.feeling: Darker, brisk fantasy craft I respect more than I feel

path_2.feeling: Taut, voyeuristic procedure that tightens like a vice

path_2.feeling: Bleak, morally knotted spy tale that fits my taste for ambiguity and consequence

path_2.feeling: Gentle, humane wonder I appreciate, though it floats past me a bit

path_3.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Inventive and frenetic, but the cartoonish sci‑fi tone keeps me at a distance.

path_3.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_3.feeling: Shaggy, low-stakes caper with charm, amiable more than gripping.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: The orchestral spectacle impresses, but the fantasia leaves me cold.

path_3.title: Millions (2004)
path_3.feeling: Sweet and well-meaning, though its whimsical morality feels a bit thin.

path_3.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_3.feeling: Pleasantly quaint but featherlight and predictable.

path_3.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_3.feeling: Moody, elegant crime tale with real moral weight, if a touch stately.

path_3.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_3.feeling: Humanely devastating, politics and personal cost woven with clarity.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Iconic mood and craft, yet I never fully connect.

path_3.title: Signs (2002)
path_3.feeling: A few tense stretches, but the faith-tinged sci‑fi feels contrived.

path_3.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Brutal and lurid in a way that feels more exploitative than illuminating.

path_3.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Lean, propulsive chase with just enough moral heft.

path_3.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_3.feeling: Winsome and fun, though its glibness keeps me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Training Day (2001)
path_3.feeling: Taut, troubling portrait of corruption that leans into macho theatrics.

path_3.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Heartfelt, but the whimsical framing of atrocity keeps me uneasy.

path_3.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_3.feeling: Polished and playful, but the wizarding whimsy doesn’t grab me.

path_3.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_3.feeling: Calming, observant look at process

path_3.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_3.feeling: Elegant, propulsive set pieces that still hum.

path_3.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_3.feeling: Visceral consumer-rot critique whose macho posture both sells and blunts it.

path_3.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_3.feeling: A stylish, relentless descent that left me rattled and sad.

path_3.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, lesson-driven animation that doesn’t engage me much.

path_3.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_3.feeling: Tight, voyeuristic suspense with moral sting.

path_3.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_3.feeling: A morally thorny identity study that lingers.

path_3.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_3.feeling: Witty, warm adventure whose charm outweighs my fairy‑tale skepticism.

path_3.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_3.feeling: Gentle and humane, though its whisper‑soft stakes keep me at a remove.

path_3.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_3.feeling: Sumptuous but airless—the grand romance leaves me cold.

path_3.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_3.feeling: Absorbing creative process with a sharp view of label politics.

path_3.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_3.feeling: Powerful and empathetic, even if the melodrama swells.

path_3.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_3.feeling: Intimate, thoughtful conversation that quietly pulled me in.

path_3.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_3.feeling: Smart, absurd riffs and philosophical silliness that mostly land.

path_3.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: The candy-colored spectacle is energetic, but the campy chaos keeps me at arm’s length

path_3.title: Millions (2004)

path_3.feeling: Pleasantly quaint civic pride, slight enough to drift away after the smile

path_3.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)

path_3.feeling: High-concept dread undercut by contrivances and sentiment that didn’t land for me

path_3.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Grim, gripping moral rot rendered with style that flirts with sensationalism

path_3.feeling: A propulsive manhunt with sturdy craft, even if it’s more thrill than scar

path_3.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_3.feeling: Clever and breezy, fun in the moment but too weightless to linger

path_3.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_3.feeling: The tonal tightrope wobbles

path_3.feeling: A darker chapter helps, but the fantasy trappings keep me less invested

path_3.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_3.feeling: Meditative and tactile, an unhurried look at impermanence that gently absorbed me

path_3.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_3.feeling: Silky, expertly paced cat-and-mouse that still hums despite its vintage gloss

path_3.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_3.feeling: Incisive and adrenalized, though its swagger sometimes undercuts the dread

path_3.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_3.feeling: Harsh and hypnotic, a cautionary spiral that left me shaken more than enlightened

path_3.feeling: Generic uplift and lesson-learning that never pierced the animated sheen for me

path_3.feeling: A precise, voyeuristic puzzle where suspicion blooms into real moral tension

path_3.feeling: Gently luminous and humane even if the pure whimsy keeps me a step outside

path_3.feeling: A candid creative struggle doubled as a quiet expose of label politics—absorbing

path_3.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_3.feeling: An empathetic, sweeping resilience tale that moved me despite its broad strokes

path_3.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_3.feeling: Talky intimacy that feels alive and honest enough to sneak up on me

path_3.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_3.feeling: Clever, literate silliness—amusing, if more smirk than sting

path_3.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Flashy, goofy space opera fun with stakes that rarely feel real to me.

path_3.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_3.feeling: A shaggy, low-stakes caper with fledgling charm but thin consequence.

path_3.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_3.feeling: Impressive craft, but the symphonic spectacle keeps me at an emotional remove.

path_3.title: Millions (2004)
path_3.feeling: Sweet and sincere with moral questions, though the kid’s-eye whimsy softens the edge.

path_3.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_3.feeling: Pleasant, parochial charm that fades quickly—too gentle for me.

path_3.title: Road to Perdition (2002)

path_3.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Stylish and clever, but the classic cool keeps me at a distance.

path_3.title: Signs (2002)
path_3.feeling: Effective setup smothered by contrived beats and tidy metaphysics.

path_3.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Relentlessly grim procedural whose moral chill lingers despite its bleakness.

path_3.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Propulsive, sturdy man-on-the-run thriller with just enough human cost.

path_3.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_3.feeling: Clever and breezy, but the hijinks feel weightless to me.

path_3.title: Training Day (2001)
path_3.feeling: Corruption as daily weather—tense, sweaty, and uncomfortably plausible.

path_3.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Sincere and affecting, but the whimsical framing blunts the horror for me.

path_3.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_3.feeling: Sleeker and darker, yet the fantasy trappings keep me less invested.

path_3.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_3.feeling: Patient, meditative process doc—quietly absorbing if a bit airy.

path_3.title: North by Northwest (1959)

path_3.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_3.feeling: Savage, stylish satire whose swagger both compels and undercuts.

path_3.feeling: Harrowing descent rendered with punishing clarity, if sometimes sensational.

path_5.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Didactic jungle fable drenched in platitudes—too juvenile for me.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Meticulous, voyeuristic suspense that feeds my love of methodical detection.

path_5.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_5.feeling: Morally thorny identity drama that lives in the gray I love.

path_5.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_5.feeling: Witty, featherlight fairy-tale romp—smart, sweet, and genuinely funny.

path_5.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_5.feeling: Gentle, beautifully observed and a bit slight for my taste.

path_5.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Handsome, sweeping romance that feels distant and overglossed.

path_5.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_5.feeling: Absorbing, warts-and-all process portrait—catnip for my doc tastes.

path_5.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, affecting survival saga, occasionally blunt but powerful.

path_5.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_5.feeling: Talky, intimate wander that earns its tenderness through lived-in conversation.

path_5.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_5.feeling: Literary silliness and philosophy gags—clever, if a touch arch for me.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Gaudy, high-concept romp whose pop energy entertains even as the cartoonish stakes keep me at arm's length.

path_5.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_5.feeling: Amiable, offbeat caper whose shaggy charm outweighs its slightness.

path_5.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_5.feeling: Opulent concert-film spectacle that I admire in pieces but find emotionally remote.

path_5.title: Millions (2004)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, whimsical caper where grief and faith go down easy, blunting the sharper edges I crave.

path_5.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_5.feeling: Gentle, communal tall tale with enough wry pride to make its small stakes satisfying.

path_5.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, father-son crime saga with moral weight and cool restraint I dig.

path_5.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_5.feeling: Humane, ground-level sweep of history where personal stakes cut deep—right in my lane.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Impeccable noir craft I respect more than I feel—kept at a distance.

path_5.title: Signs (2002)
path_5.feeling: Moody setup with thin payoff and tidy metaphysics that don't land for me.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: True-crime cruelty rendered with relentless bleakness that feels more punishing than illuminating.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Lean, propulsive man-on-the-run thriller that delivers tension if not much texture.

path_5.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_5.feeling: Saucy teen lark that amuses in spots but skews too glib for my taste.

path_5.title: Training Day (2001)
path_5.feeling: Tense, morally slippery cop chess that scratches my crime-drama itch.

path_5.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_5.feeling: A bold tonal gamble whose sentiment works in parts but softens the harsher truths I prefer confronted.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_5.feeling: Slick, darker YA fantasy that entertains without ever feeling like my thing.

path_5.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_5.feeling: Meditative, process-focused art doc that rewards patience and observation—very much my speed.

path_5.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_5.feeling: Silky, playful chase craft I enjoy as construction more than as human stakes.

path_5.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_5.feeling: Bracing, stylized provocation I respect, even if the posture wears thin for me.

path_5.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_5.feeling: Visceral, formally bracing spiral that's powerful and punishing in equal measure.

path_5.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Didactic jungle fable with tidy morals and thin texture that leave me unmoved.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Taut voyeurist mystery with clean gears and simmering moral unease that keeps me hooked.

path_5.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_5.feeling: Moral quagmire of identity and complicity that I find absorbing and thought-sticky.

path_5.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_5.feeling: Witty storybook swashbuckle that charms without cloying—my kind of fantasy.

path_5.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_5.feeling: Gently wondrous slice-of-life whose quiet magic I admire more than adore.

path_5.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Handsomely mounted wartime romance that feels remote and over-swooned to me.

path_5.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_5.feeling: Intimate, process-rich music doc with industry friction—squarely in my wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, expansive survival drama that hits hard even when it swells.

path_5.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_5.feeling: Talky, lived-in night of connection that favors honesty over contrivance—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_5.feeling: Wordy, wry period goof with enough wit and philosophy to keep me grinning.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, pulpy space opera that's fun in the moment but light on aftertaste.

path_5.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_5.feeling: Shaggy, low-stakes caper with charm and heart—agreeable more than essential.

path_5.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_5.feeling: Lavish experiment whose wonder leaves me cold.

path_5.title: Millions (2004)
path_5.feeling: Warm grief-and-grace fable that leans tidy and precious for my taste.

path_5.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_5.feeling: Quaint communal uplift with gentle laughs—pleasant, predictable comfort.

path_5.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_5.feeling: Moody father-son crime odyssey with moral weight and immaculate craft.

path_5.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_5.feeling: Humanist, clear-eyed epic of survival that hits my social-realist sweet spot.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Handsome and clever, but its cool remove keeps me at a distance.

path_5.title: Signs (2002)
path_5.feeling: Neat setup, thin payoff—atmosphere over substance.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: True-crime brutality that feels exploitative more than illuminating.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Lean, smart chase thriller that holds my attention without lingering.

path_5.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_5.feeling: Buoyant and slick, with charm that outpaces its thinness.

path_5.title: Training Day (2001)
path_5.feeling: Gritty, morally thorny cop drama that keeps the screws turning.

path_5.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Sincere, but the whimsy-atrocity blend sits uneasily with me.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_5.feeling: Handsomer, darker chapter, still too theme-park tidy for my taste.

path_5.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_5.feeling: Meditative process doc that quietly fascinates me.

path_5.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_5.feeling: A master-class chase, brisk and witty with just enough edge.

path_5.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_5.feeling: Savage, stylish provocation whose critique lands even if the swagger grates.

path_5.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_5.feeling: Unflinching descent that’s punishing but compelling.

path_5.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Didactic jungle fable whose family-friendly lessons feel weightless to me.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Taut voyeuristic puzzle that nails suspense and complicity.

path_5.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_5.feeling: Haunting identity-and-guilt drama right in my moral-gray wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_5.feeling: Witty, warm fairy-tale romp that charms without cloying.

path_5.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_5.feeling: Gently enchanting and beautifully observed, a touch too airy for me.

path_5.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous wartime pining that feels stately and remote.

path_5.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_5.feeling: Absorbing creative-process doc with industry friction that adds stakes.

path_5.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, affecting resilience saga

path_5.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_5.feeling: Intimate, talky wander that earns its ache through honesty.

path_5.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_5.feeling: Witty, neurotic farce—more clever smirks than belly laughs.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Inventive, flashy space romp that entertains while skimming light on texture for me.

path_5.title: Bottle Rocket (1996)
path_5.feeling: Low-key caper with amiable chemistry and small, lived-in stakes I enjoy.

path_5.title: Fantasia (1940)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous craft, but the whimsical pageantry leaves me cold.

path_5.title: Millions (2004)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, moral fable with grief notes, a bit too sugar-glazed for my taste.

path_5.title: Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain, The (1995)
path_5.feeling: Gentle, quaint crowd-pleaser—pleasant, tidy, modestly funny.

path_5.title: Road to Perdition (2002)
path_5.feeling: A stately, moody crime tale with father–son stakes squarely in my lane.

path_5.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
path_5.feeling: Human, clear-eyed endurance through upheaval—exactly the kind of social drama that grips me.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Stylish and cool to the touch for me—admire the craft more than I feel it.

path_5.title: Signs (2002)
path_5.feeling: Moody setup, thin payoff—the sentiment and suspense don’t fully land for me.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Brutal true-crime misery that reads more exploitative than illuminating to me.

path_5.title: Fugitive, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Lean, engaging man-on-the-run thriller that delivers solid momentum and stakes.

path_5.title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986)
path_5.feeling: Snappy, charming teen lark that amuses more than it resonates.

path_5.title: Training Day (2001)
path_5.feeling: Gritty, morally thorny day-from-hell that scratches my crime-drama itch.

path_5.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Whimsy wedded to atrocity lands more tidy than truthful for me.

path_5.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
path_5.feeling: Polished fantasy adventure that entertains but doesn’t hit my register.

path_5.title: Rivers and Tides (2001)
path_5.feeling: Observational, meditative art portrait that lets process speak—my speed.

path_5.title: North by Northwest (1959)
path_5.feeling: Silky, propulsive chase craft I appreciate even as it stays light on aftertaste.

path_5.title: Fight Club (1999)
path_5.feeling: Visceral, provocative spiral with bite that mostly hits my cynical sweet spot.

path_5.title: Requiem for a Dream (2000)
path_5.feeling: Unflinching descent whose formal intensity serves a humane gut-punch.

path_5.title: Lion King, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Sincere jungle fable whose lesson-forward, family tone feels too tidy for me.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: A taut, voyeuristic mystery with domestic-noir tension I savor.

path_5.title: Mother Night (1996)
path_5.feeling: Identity, guilt, and complicity explored with the moral gray I’m drawn to.

path_5.title: Princess Bride, The (1987)
path_5.feeling: Witty, storybook swashbuckle that charms even if the fairy-tale gloss keeps me at a distance.

path_5.title: My Neighbor Totoro (Tonari no Totoro) (1988)
path_5.feeling: Tender, gentle fantasy that I appreciate more in mood than in impact.

path_5.title: English Patient, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Handsome, earnest romance that feels more stately than lived-in to me.

path_5.title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)
path_5.feeling: Candid, process-rich music doc with industry friction that engages my head.

path_5.title: Color Purple, The (1985)
path_5.feeling: A humane, bruising saga whose empathy and stakes carry me past its sentiment.

path_5.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
path_5.feeling: Talky, honest walk-and-talk that favors lived moments over neat catharsis—my speed.

path_5.title: Love and Death (1975)
path_5.feeling: Wordy, deadpan silliness that tickles more with wit than belly laughs.
